titleStmt.title: John Quincy Adams Diary Digital Project

div.p:
Wednesday morning September 17th: 1794. I embarked on board the ship Alfred, Stephen Macey, commander, for London; together with my brother and a servant. Dr: Welsh and Mr: W. Smith accompanied us on board the ship, and returned on shore as soon as we were fairly under weigh— My friends Daniel Sargent junr & Nathan Frazier junr went with us down as far as the light-house. At ten A.M. we weighed anchor, & just at noon were a-breast of the light.— my friends then left us to return home. “The name of your ship said Frazier is auspicious”—and alluding to the new French Calendar, “you depart[”] said he, “on the day of Virtue; I hope you will return upon the day of Rewards.” The pain of separation from my friends and Country, was felt as poignantly by me, at the moment when these two young men left the ship, as it ever has been at any period of my life. It was like the
severing the last string from the Heart. I looked back at their boat as long as it could be seen, and when it had got out of sight, I did not, but I could have turned my eye and wept. By two P.M. we were fairly at sea; the weather clouded up the wind for a moment veered to the East, and we began to apprehend a difficulty to clear the Capes; but the western gale finally prevailed a slight shower of rain was succeeded by a beautiful Rainbow in the East a pledge of fair weather for the morrow, and a livid corner broke forth in the west, from whence the clouds were very soon dispelled from the sky, and left us for the night a cloudless canopy over our heads and a fresh western breeze to waft us on our course.

Thursday September 18. 1794. Fresh breeze from the Southwest through the whole of a perfectly clear day. The vessel rolls not a little and our fresh water sailors were most of them sick. the morning exhibited a boundless Ocean to our view. And at noon the Captain told me he supposed we had reached George’s Bank, which is 35 leagues distant from Cape-Cod. On this bank the Captain says he met with a violent current, when he last came from Europe, which prevented his getting across for two or three days though with favourable winds. What can be the cause of these temporary currents?— Indeed it appears to me that on this Bank there is a constant current setting eastward. the shortness and irregularity of the seas so very distinguishable from any thing on either side of it and which I well remember to have observed when passing this place heretofore, convince me of this fact.
Governor Pownal I am told has written a pamphlet on this subject. Memm: to consult it.

We saw this day only two small schooners one of them holding her course westward, and the other nearly the same with ourselves; she outsailed us however very considerably; & at night had nearly got out of our sight a-head. The Alfred among other of her merits is a dull sailor I perceive; and with a very fresh breeze goes not more than 6 knots before the wind.

She is moreover old, crazy and leaky; and many of my friends in Boston who dissuaded me from taking passage in her prophesied that she would never reach her destined port in Europe.— But no other vessel presents itself to sail for a considerable length of Time from Boston. To go to New-York with all my baggage, would have been tedious, expensive, and after all upon an uncertainty whether I should there find a speedier or better conveyance. I had from a variety of causes been already detained so long since my appointment, as to have given me a great degree of anxiety; and I could not justify to my own sense of duty, the omission of any opportunity to depart, however indifferent the vehicle: as to the ship I was in hopes that her reputation was worse than she deserved; the owners protested most solemnly that she was a good ship. The Captain who knows her very well, declares he would willingly go in her to any part of the world: Mr: Wainwright, who went in her the last voyage she made to Europe, says she is a good ship, though a little leaky, and in opposition to this concurrent tho’ partly interested testimony I had nothing but a general opinion
opinion among the merchants in Boston, that she was a very bad ship to warrant me in incurring a further delay. I therefore took my passage in her, though from what I have hitherto observed of her I have no reason to think that her character was improperly estimated. Her present texture is certainly feeble and frail enough for an atlantic voyage, and I place a much greater dependance upon a pleasant passage, than upon any merit of hers to land us safely on the other side— But the dye is cast, and we are now only to make of our bargain the best we can.

Friday September 19. 1794. We saw this morning a schooner on our Quarter, which we presumed to be the same that was a head of us last night. The night was calm & this morning somewhat foggy. the winds all this day were light and our schooner soon left us out of sight behind her.

I slept but little last night; or indeed none at all; and was obliged two or three times to go on deck to alleviate in some measure the tediousness of my situation by some variety. In addition to the usual inconvenience of being on board a ship at sea; the perpetual creaking and rocking of joints in this, not only indicates the very precarious state of the vessel itself, but keeps up such a ceaseless noise as is indeed very unfavourable to sleep.

Our company consists of Captain Stephen Macey, the Master. Two of his brothers, one acting as first mate and the other as a common seaman. Turner. 2d: mate. Cathcart a Seaman. Petera frenchman; two other sailors both raw hands. Jack Burtinet, an English Lad of about 18 who acts as steward; and a black fellow who is the Cook.— This is the ship’s crew. Mr: Dudley Walker of
Boston is our only fellow passenger.

Saturday September 20. 1794. 4th: Pleasant weather the former part of the day. about noon the weather thickened up very much, and had the appearance of portending a southerly storm. The wind however settled before night at the westward: and two or three fresh squalls cleared away much of the obscurity from the horizon. We saw this day a brig bearing westward, but came not near her.

Sunday September 21. 1794 5th A fine fresh breeze all night and all this day. The vessel rolls very much and our new sailors have not yet recovered the accustomed tone of their stomachs. Tilly, my Servant is by far the sickest person on board: he can do nothing, and indeed requires considerable attendance himself.— I can yet get no sleep, and suffer in consequence of this inability; particularly in my spirits. Saw a ship this morning in the fog.

6th. Monday September 22. 1794. This day the sun crosses the Line; the weather was very rough and the wind high; the sea running so as to make our deadlights necessary to be put up in the cabin. the wind however was favourable, and carried us at a great rate; vessel rolling intolerably. towards night the wind died away and we were obliged to crowd sail in order to keep her before the sea. Saw a schooner this morning bearing same course with ourselves and she kept approaching us till night.— Saw likewise a brig this afternoon bearing westward.

Tuesday September 23. 1794. Brisk northwesterly breezes in the night. Vessel pitched very much. I slept however a little. Our Schooner kept us company the whole day. And at night was almost within speaking distance. the winds light and weather pleasant through the day. The Captain this afternoon caught a dolphin, from the bow of the ship with a grain; an instrument something resembling an harpoon with three points each having but one flew. the dolphin was about four feet long, and had several flying fish and other small fry in its mouth when caught. in the course of ten minutes after it was taken on board its colours varied repeatedly, and assumed by a turns a green a blue and a yellow shade. This fish they say is good food, but our mate says it will be converted into rank poison, by being dried twelve hours in the Sun.

Our weather had been remarkably pleasant the whole day but at night the wind got round to the East of South and freshened very rapidly. the sky in that quarter was very thick and black, and it lightened nearly all round the horizon. At Midnight the moon changed in the midst of an extremely violent squall, during the worst part of which a large ship was discovered by one of our men, bearing directly down upon us, and so near as left us barely time to get away from her. A Southeasterly gale continued with repeated squalls and heavy winds for about six hours. One of our Seamen told me that in the midst of the gale a coppresant (as he pronounced it) came on board. It is a small meteor resembling a ball of fire which in these heavy gales sometimes comes on board, and moves upward by the side of a mast until it reaches the top, which it
usually does when the gale is at its highest pitch; and it afterwards descends again and disappears. I asked the Seaman, whether he ever heard that these things were the spirits of sailors lost at Sea; but he said no. whether he never heard this tale of superstition or whether he was ashamed of it, I know not; but I am very sure that this phenomenon was in some respect or other portentous to the mind of this man.

Wednesday September 24. 1794. At about 6 in the morning the wind hauled back to the westward, and gave us through this day a very fresh and favourable gale. In the bad weather of last night we lost our schooner who had accompanied us the two preceding days, and we have not seen her this day. We saw however a ship following a western course, but came not near her. The forenoon weather was rough: the remains of the last night’s turbulence, but towards night, the swell subsided considerably, and left us a delightful breeze.

Thursday September 25: 1794. Our breeze continued very fresh, our swell rather high. The water appeared to me to have changed its colour, and the Sea irregular or as one of our Seamen termed it up in heaps. I thought we must by this time have reached the banks of Newfoundland, and upon examining our Captain’s chart this morning found the conclusion strongly corroborated in my mind.— Captain Macey’s knowledge is all practical, he has very little theory, and may be termed
illiterate without injury to his reputation. he himself says he never was but a fortnight at school. but he has followed a sea-faring life these fifteen years. The premises therefore upon which he grounds his opinion of approaching the banks, are not his calculations, but the sight of fishing schooners and of birds called Haglets which are most frequently numerous and are in some measure peculiar to this place. We saw no fishing schooners the former part of this day; and very few Haglets. The Captain concludes therefore that we have not reached the banks.

This afternoon we saw a ship nearly a-head of us. and as she held her course westward we very soon met—about 300 tons, and hoisted american colours which we likewise did. we pass’d very near to each other but without speaking. Our Captain seems rather averse to speak with any thing. The reason may be that he thinks in time of war between the great naval powers; the less a neutral vessel is meddled with the better her luck.—

Just as we were going to bed at about 10. this Evening, the mate who kept the watch came and informed the captain, that there was a little fishing schooner laying too to close upon our quarter. We are therefore upon the banks.— Without the help of the schooner I believe we have been on them the whole day.

Friday September 26. 1794. This morning early we discovered another fishing schooner laying to; at about 8 A.M. we came to ourselves and sounded but without
finding any bottom at about 140 fathom. a couple of cod-hooks were baited and annexed to the lead but we were not more successful in fishing than in sounding. after about half an hour of this sport exhausted our Captain’s patience, and we proceeded upon our voyage with a gale still favourable and fresh. A brig pass’d us at about noon steering to the South & eastward.

Saturday September 27. 1794. We at length esteem ourselves to be fairly off the Banks of Newfoundland, and as one evidence of the fact, this is the first day since we left our port, that we have been without seeing any other vessel. The breeze has been fresh and the weather fair; but nothing has occurred deserving to be recorded.

Sunday September 28. 1794. The observations of yesterday may be repeated. whatever benefit wind and weather can confer upon an old, crazy, leaky, dull-sailing ship, we still enjoy. She was this day so quiet, that for the first time since our departure I attempted to write, and commenced upon this Journal, which has already been too long delayed. I found I could make out to write rather better than I expected.

The mate said he saw a vessel this afternoon from one of the tops; but we could not descry her from the deck. The sight of a vessel at sea in time of Peace is always a pleasing thing. It serves in some measure to variegate the scene, which is naturally dull and monotonous. It excites curiosity and conjecture respecting her destination and sometimes her construction. It affords a sort of “Society,” at a Time, when we are cut off from all intercourse with mankind, and reconciles us to the hardships we
are suffering by exhibiting to us other objects participating with them. Of this satisfaction however we shall probably enjoy but little for some time to come as we have now got into the midst of the Atlantic; and shall for several days proceed more and more distant from any land.—

Monday September 29. 1794. Saw nothing through the day. At length at about noon the wind failed us the afternoon and evening was calm, dull and rainy weather. We amused ourselves as well as we could with cards. These and a back-gammon Table constitute the principle part of our diversion. To get rid of our Time is not the most easy occupation. For in a ship of 168 Tons of perpetual rolling even in the smoothest sea, and with the most friendly breeze, incapacitates for any action of mind. We can write nor read, but very little at a Time, and that little to small purpose. Thinking is worse than all, and the only means of removing the burden of Time which hangs so heavy on our hands is by pursuing some sort of sport. Nor is even this without its toil; for the cards, the dice, the men all seem to acquire that animation of which we lose so much; they dance away from their places or slip through our hands, and leave us in confusion to begin again the disconcerted game. After several hours of calm, a breeze sprung up at the close of this Evening, & again carries us on our course.

Tuesday September 30. 1794. We had a favourable breeze all night and this forenoon, but from noon till midnight was as near a total calm as has been at any time since we sailed. 12 at night a southwesterly breeze started which we hope will freshen.

How far we are advanced upon our voyage it is difficult to say. The Captain is studiously mysterious as to his longitude. I have no doubt however but if ever we make land, he will then immediately discover that his longitude tallies with it to a tenth part of a degree. I have seen these practices of old, and am satisfied there is as much quackery in navigation, as in Law or physic

We have now been 14 days out of Boston. And we have not had 6 hours of contrary winds during the whole of that Time; about 30 hours of calm have been abundantly compensated, by fresh breezes of the fairest winds, which have blown to the utmost of the vessel’s bearing. Yet if any thing of our Captain’s real calculations can be discovered it is that we have not yet run 30 degrees of longitude.— If they are right, 36 days as favourable as those we have hitherto had, will be barely sufficient to carry us over. By making therefore the allowance of an usual degree of unfavourable weather, I think we may estimate our passage at 50 days. Had our vessel been but
but a commonly dull sailor, we should at this time have crossed at least two thirds of our way; and might hope in 6 days more to be landed.
